document_title: New Insights into the Bacterial Fitness-Associated Mechanisms Revealed by the Characterization of Large Plasmids of an Avian Pathogenic E. coli
summary_full: This study characterizes the plasmids pChi7122-2, pChi7122-3, and pChi7122-4 from the avian pathogenic E. coli (APEC) strain χ7122. The plasmids pChi7122-2 and pChi7122-3 encode an ABC iron transport system (eitABCD) and type IV fimbriae, respectively, while pChi7122-4 is cryptic. A novel sugar utilization pathway operon, found in Salmonella but not other E. coli strains, was identified on pChi7122-2. Experiments evaluating the role of these plasmids individually and in combination revealed their influence on biofilm formation, bile and acid tolerance, and interaction with intestinal epithelial cells. The study also investigated the effect of different host strain backgrounds on these plasmid-associated phenotypes, highlighting the complex interplay between plasmids, host genetics, and environmental conditions in shaping ExPEC fitness and diversity.
key_findings: Sequencing of pChi7122-2 and pChi7122-3 revealed an ABC iron transport system (eitABCD) and type IV fimbriae, respectively, and identified a novel sugar utilization pathway operon on pChi7122-2 shared with Salmonella.
Plasmids influenced biofilm formation, with pChi7122-3 significantly enhancing it at host temperatures (37°C and 42°C).
Large plasmids conferred bile resistance in an E. coli K-12 background and affected acid tolerance in the APEC wild-type background, with pChi7122-3 increasing survival in acidic conditions.
APEC strains, regardless of plasmid presence, associated with and invaded human intestinal epithelial cells without disrupting tight junctions.
The presence of plasmids, particularly pChi7122-3, increased biofilm formation at host temperatures (37°C and 42°C), while plasmidless strains formed more biofilm at 30°C.
future_research_fields: Investigating the in vivo expression conditions and role of the eitABCD iron uptake system and the novel sugar utilization pathways in APEC and Salmonella.
Elucidating the specific mechanisms by which pChi7122-3 confers enhanced acid tolerance.
Further exploring the distinct functions of the four identified factor-driven biofilms (plasmidless, plasmid, rough-LPS, and O-LPS mediated) in bacterial persistence and virulence.
Determining the precise roles of toxin-antitoxin modules and other plasmid-encoded factors in APEC fitness and persistence.

conclusions: The study successfully sequenced and characterized plasmids pChi7122-2, pChi7122-3, and pChi7122-4 from APEC strain χ7122, identifying key genes for iron transport and fimbriae, and a novel sugar utilization pathway. The research demonstrates that these plasmids, individually or in combination, significantly influence bacterial fitness traits such as biofilm formation, bile, and acid tolerance, with effects modulated by the host strain background. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of fitness and diversity in ExPEC, highlighting the crucial role of extrachromosomal elements in bacterial adaptation and survival.
impact_statement: This research elucidates how large plasmids contribute to the fitness and adaptability of avian pathogenic E. coli, offering crucial insights into bacterial survival mechanisms relevant to both animal and potentially human health.
